Commitment to the Community

BASF Corporation has a long tradition of operating its facilities in the safest possible manner. BASF also
believes in being a responsible corporate citizen and maintaining open, constructive dialogue with our
neighbors. These principles are an integral part of our corporate vision statement and values. We believe that
sharing this information with our neighbors makes good sense. By doing so, we believe the community will
better understand how safe and ecologically sound BASF operations are.

Policies

BASF Corporation has the following Corporate Guidelines related to environmental, health and safety:
1) We produce products that are safe to manufacture, use and dispose.
2) We assist our customers to use our products safely and in an environmentally sound manner. We provide them with information on correct handling of our products.
3) We minimize the impact on mankind and the environment during production, storage, transportation, marketing and use of our products.
4) Economic considerations do not take priority over environmental protection, health and safety.
5) An important contribution to "Sustainable Development" is our involvement in the "Responsible Care" initiative worldwide. This applies to our products and services in all our businesses and affiliates.
6) We are committed to making continuous improvements in safety, health and environmental protection. We do this acting on our own initiative and in consultation with recognized regulatory authorities. We take any action judged to be necessary, whether or not dictated by statutory obligation or official regulations.
7) We encourage safety, environmental and health awareness among employees.
8) We regard it as an important corporate duty to advance science and technology in order to improve safety and environmental protection.
9) We carefully weigh the potential benefits and risks of new discoveries and technologies in dialogue with scientists and society before

deciding on how to proceed.
10)We pursue an open dialogue with all relevant opinion leaders in society. Our goals are to promote and strengthen mutual understanding and deepen trust in what we do.

BASF Construction Chemicals of Brighton, Colorado, formerly known as Degussa (and ChemRex, Inc.) began production at this location in December of 1997. Toluene diisocyanate is the regulated substance stored and used within the plant.

TDI is received in 45,000-pound tank trucks and transferred to a 64,000-pound holding tank within the building. The handling of TDI in BASF's processes is completely computer controlled. Prior to use in manufacturing, TDI is pumped from the bulk storage tank into one of three 2350-pound capacity "day" tanks. TDI is then pumped from the "day" tanks to mixer heads in the intermediate area, reacting and consuming the material. This "activation" procedure is controlled through an Inbatch computer control system which will shut down operations and sound an alarm if outside close tolerances.

BASF has specific standard operating procedures and training in the offloading of tankers to bulk storage. The TDI off-loading SOP specifies that a trained BASF employee wearing proper PPE will be present during the entire offload procedure, including transfer hose hookup, product transfer, offload and during removal of the transfer hose. Any leak or rupture will be observed and proper steps taken to shut down transfer to minimize TDI loss. An isocyanate emergency stop is located at the offload station that automatically stops the offload operation when activated.

BASF has a comprehensive contingency (emergency response) plan that includes procedures for chemical spills/releases, medical emergencies, natural disasters, and environmental issues. This plan identifies the Emergency Coordinator, Team Leaders, and Em

ergency Response Team members and their responsibilities and training requirements. BASF also has procedures for coordinating response with local response agencies.

A vent was installed in the TDI bulk storage room that would minimize the build-up of, TDI vapors and decrease the potential for release of vapors into other areas of the facility in the event of a small leak within the room. The TDI day tank room has an active exhaust that passes through a carbon scrubber before being vented out of the facility. Sensor systems were installed in the bulk storage and "day" tank storage that monitor TDI levels in the rooms. Remote displays allow employees to check for levels of TDI down to 0.2 parts per billion prior to entering the storage areas. If levels rise above 5 ppb, the building security company will receive an alarm and notify the facility emergency contact. Our maintenance, department has a preventative maintenance program that includes critical TDI safety and testing of equipment.
